page.title: 09GIBBET
page.content: Jack Upperton's Gibbet is located in Upper Wepham Woods, at a crossroads 6R 051078. A Gibbet was an iron cage to keep an offender inside and stop the family from taking the body. In the 18th century many crimes were capital offences. Upperton was hanged and gibbeted for attempted robbery of the Royal Mail which William Baldry was carrying on horseback from or to Steyning. Jack Upperton was sentenced to death at East Grinstead. The Judge's sentence conformed with the custom of the time, which was that the criminal should be gibbeted as near as possible to the place of the offence as a warning to others. Today a metal post 6 feet high marks the spot. Originally the gibbet stood on open downland, today the forest has encroached on it.
